cover_page.title: City Center Park Redesign
cover_page.author: JPP Egineering and Urban Planning
cover_page.audience: Members of the board of trustees and residants of the city of Kirkland Washington

tbl_cont.section: Introduction Background Purpose Action Plan Feasibility Conclusion

p.crnt_cond: Located at 111 Waverly Way in Kirkland, City Center Park currently serves as the city's second largest communal gathering space within city limits. The large expanse of land has become overgrown with weeds and blackberry bushes.
p.subj_hist: As the site of the former junior high school which burned down in 1987, this land was left in disrepair for over a year before members of the local neighborhoods banned together to bring purpose back to the land. Over the years since the fire, different features have been added progressively. Starting with the creation of the winding path up to a senic lookout point over Lake Washington and then building a small play ground out of local recycled materials. The potential of this space is obvious to those who live around it.

p.scope: In the summer of 2017, the city of Kenmore hopes to begin construction on the vacant lot turned community park in hopes of realizing its value to the community and the organizations within it.
When completed this project will bring greatly added value to the city and to its residence in many forms.
p.objective: The proposed project includes a multi-purpose turf sports feild with small grandstand seating to serve as a practice area and play space for local teams. It will include a ecofriendly play space by updating and reinforcing the existing structure made out of local recycled materials. All surrounded by patches of community gardens for town residents to manage and attend to. The existing lookout point at the top of the park's hill will be enhanced with a sculptural totem pole designed and carved by local artists and craftsman.
p.goal: The goals of redesigning city center park are to: - Preserve, protect, and improve parkland and recreational opportunities. - Anticipate the needs of the changing community and structure programs and facilities accordingly. - Enhance the cityâ€™s arts, cultural and historic assets. - Enrich the lives of residents. - And build a healthier community.
